article_title: It's a jam-packed, family fun weekend in Charleston
article_text:
Crowds packed onto the dance floor to show off their moves at a previous Latin American Festival.

With the October events calendar now in full swing, expect to see the lineup of events expanding over the next few weeks. In the more immediate future, this weekend is full of family-friendly offerings. So take a look and get to planning.

SaturdayHogs for the Cause

Hogs for the Cause, a fundraiser that draws 90 top barbecue teams and 15,000 eaters to New Orleans annually, is making its Charleston debut this weekend. A fundraiser for pediatric brain cancer outreach, the inaugural Charleston event will feature a day of music, food and more. Pitmasters from across the state will be serving up samples, including Rodney Scott (Scott's Bar-B-Que of Hemingway), Jimmy Hagood (Food for the Southern Soul), John Haire (Nick's BBQ), Conyers Family BBQ (Manning), Aaron Siegel (Fiery Ron's Home Team BBQ), Mark Behr (Sweatman's BBQ of Holly Hill), and Lynn and Norton Hughes (Shuler's Bar-B-Que of Latta).

A number of visiting chefs from New Orleans will be in attendance, as well, including Justin Devillier (executive chef of La Petite Grocery, James Beard Award finalist for Best Chef: South, and Bravo TV "Top Chef" Season 11 contestant), Aaron Burgau (executive chef of Patois) and Ryan Prewitt (executive chef of Peche, James Beard Award winner of Best Chef: South, and James Beard Award winner for Best New Restaurant). Charleston's Sean Brock also will be on site. The music lineup will feature performances by Drive-By Truckers, Heartless Bastards, Soul Rebels Brass Band, Whiskey Shivers and Charleston's own Sol Driven Train and Dead 27s.

When: Today, gates open at 11 a.m.

Where: The Grove at Patriots Point, 40 Patriots Point Road, Mount Pleasant

Price: $30-$200; children under 10 get in free

For more info: www.hogscharleston.org

SundayLatin American Festival

Celebrate the sights and sounds of the Latin world at the 23rd annual Latin American Festival. Attendees will have an opportunity to groove to Latin music by UltimaNota and Bachata Flow, participate in a salsa dance contest, catch performances by Capoeira Charleston and the Buen Ache Dance Company, and more.

After folks work up an appetite on the dance floor, where DJ Luigi of Latin Groove will spin salsa, merengue, cumbia, bachata and reggaeton hits, they're invited to indulge in authentic cuisine from Mexico, Central and South America, and the Caribbean, along with traditional festival foods and beverages.

The family-friendly festival also will feature jump castles, rides, crafts and more. Outside food, alcohol or coolers are not permitted. Dogs are not allowed.

When: Noon-6 p.m. Sunday.

Where: Wannamaker County Park, 8888 University Blvd., North Charleston.

Price: $10 for adults, $5 for college students and military with valid ID, Gold Pass holders and children ages 12 and under get in free.

For more info: www.CharlestonCountyParks.com/laf or 795-4386

Oktoberfest

The 16-day Oktoberfest wraps up in Germany on Sunday, and locals will be able to celebrate the arrival of fall (minus the airfare) at the 11th annual Oktoberfest event on Daniel Island. As in years past, Blackbaud Stadium will transform into an outdoor festival complete with seasonal beer, traditional grilled brats, oompah music and all things German. The family-friendly event will host a variety of games and field-day contests, and will have jump castles and activities for children.

When: Noon-5 p.m. Sunday

Where: Blackbaud Stadium, 1990 Daniel Island Drive, Daniel Island

Price: $5 in advance, $8 the day of; children 12 and under get in free

For more info: www.charlestonbattery.com or 971-4625

Scrumptious Summerville Kitchen Tour

In celebration of its 12th year, the annual Scrumptious Summerville Kitchen Tour benefiting Children in Crisis will feature a "baker's dozen" of homes on the tour. Appealing to those who enjoy home tours and good food, the Summerville Kitchen Tour combines the two, offering attendees the chance to get a glimpse into private homes while nibbling on offerings from local chefs. This year's route will run along Gadsden Street, Salisbury Drive and Linwood Lane, offering a mix of historic and modern homes. New to both Summerville and this year's Kitchen Tour will be Five Loaves Cafe, Toast!, Graze and Triangle Char & Bar; additional restaurant participants include A.W. Shucks, Leaf, Blossom, The Ice House and the Charleston Tea Plantation. Local musicians are scheduled to perform in each home or garden, and area florists will provide floral arrangements.

When: 1-5 p.m. Sunday

Where: Gadsden Street, Salisbury Drive and Linwood Lane in Summerville

Price: $50

For more info: www.scrumptioussummerville.com

Charleston Beach Music and Shag Festival

As South Carolina's state dance is the shag, it should come as no surprise that there are numerous clubs and events revolving around it. This weekend, the Beach Music and Shag Preservation Society of S.C. will host its ninth annual Beach Music and Shag Festival. Live music will be provided throughout the day by the Fantastic Shakers, Rhonda McDaniel and Jimbo Durham & Shag Attack. DJs Gerry Scott and Andy Todd will entertain between sets. Food and drinks will be available for purchase on-site; a cash bar will be available. Coolers are not permitted.

When: 2-10 p.m. Sunday

Where: Holliday Alumni Center at The Citadel, 171 Moultrie Ave.

Price: $25 for members and $30 for nonmembers

For more info: http://charleston.beachmusic.co

Multi-day eventsGreek Fall Festival

Held over Mother's Day weekend for more than 40 years, the folks behind the popular Charleston Greek Festival decided to add a second event to capitalize on the event's success. This year marks the second Greek Fall Festival, an event that's all about celebrating Greek culture, food and entertainment. The fall festival will still offer authentic food items such as gyros, though with a smaller selection, but will add multiple wine tasting tents. While attendees eat and drink their way through the festival grounds, they'll also be able to enjoy Greek music performed by two live bands, folk dance performances, Greek-themed vendors and more. Free parking and a shuttle service will be available at the Medical University of South Carolina, off Lockwood Boulevard.

When: 11 a.m.-10 p.m. today and noon-6 p.m. Sunday

Where: Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, 30 Race St.

Price: $5 for adults, $3 for students and seniors; active military and kids 12 and younger get in free

For more info: CharlestonGreekFestival.com

Boone Hall Pumpkin Patch

The days are getting shorter, crisp temperatures are starting to make an appearance and pumpkin-flavored everything is everywhere. It's official, fall is here. For those looking to get in on all the fall fun, consider heading out to the Boone Hall Pumpkin Patch. With a highlight of an eight-acre corn maze, which this year pays tribute to Chick-fil-A's "Eat Mor Chikin" slogan, the pumpkin patch features numerous other events to entertain the whole family. Complete with a goatwalk and rabbit enclosure, a giant slide, a jump pillow, a hay mountain, hay rides, a rock climbing wall, the pick-your-own-pumpkin patch and more, there's more than enough going on to make a day out of it.

When: Through Oct. 31, 9 a.m.-6 p.m. Mondays-Saturdays and 11 a.m.-6 p.m. Sundays

Where: Boone Hall Farms, 2521 North Highway 17, Mount Pleasant

Price: $10 for ages 3 and up, with a special deal on Tuesdays where one adult admission is free with each paid $10 child's admission

For more info: www.boonehallpumpkinpatch.com
